G.L. c. 185, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185, § 1 and G.L. c. 218, § 19, as this is a civil action where the amount in controversy is within the statutory limit.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185, § 1 and G.L. c. 218, § 19, as this is a civil action where the amount in controversy is within the statutory limit.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant’s real property is located in Lowell, and this action arises out of the Defendant’s obligations as a landlord at said property.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by which the landlord guarantees that tenants will not be subjected to unreasonable interference with their use and enjoyment of the leased premises.

*Fitz-Enos v. Dahlberg,* 90 Mass. App. C.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants’ rights to quiet enjoyment and held landlords liable for circumstances where the property’s condition substantially impairs a tenant’s use and enjoyment.

*Dartmouth v. Silva,* 198 Mass. 209 (190.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants’ rights to quiet enjoyment and held landlords liable for circumstances where the property’s condition substantially impairs a tenant’s use and enjoyment.
*Dartmouth v. Silva,* 198 Mass. 209 (190.case_name: American Circular Loom Co. v. Wilson
*Dartmouth v. Silva,* 198 Mass. 209 (190.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns patent ownership, fiduciary duties of a corporate officer/employee, and constructive trusts over patents, not landlord–tenant law or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not address tenants’ rights, quiet enjoyment, or landlord liability for conditions impairing use of leased premises. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the stated proposition about Massachusetts courts upholding tenants’ quiet enjoyment rights.
*Dartmouth v. Silva,* 198 Mass. 209 (190.relevant_excerpt: The opinion is entirely focused on disputes over patents and fiduciary duties between a corporation and its superintendent/director, and contains no discussion of landlord–tenant relationships, quiet enjoyment, or habitability issues.

*Simon v. Solomon,* 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants’ rights to quiet enjoyment and held landlords liable for circumstances where the property’s condition substantially impairs a tenant’s use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon,* 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses Massachusetts tenants’ rights to quiet enjoyment and landlord liability when conditions substantially interfere with use of the premises. The court discusses the statutory and common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment, interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 broadly to protect tenants, and holds that repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions that impaired the tenant’s use constituted interference with quiet enjoyment and a breach of the landlord’s duty, subjecting the landlord to damages and attorney’s fees. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts uphold tenants’ quiet enjoyment rights and hold landlords liable where conditions substantially impair use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon,* 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes… The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The Defendant’s inaction regarding the mold and inadequate ventilation system reflects a failure to make repairs needed for the premises to remain habitable, as required under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and relevant Massachusetts housing code provisions, including 105 CMR 410.750.

105 CMR 410.750.proposition: The Defendant’s inaction regarding the mold and inadequate ventilation system reflects a failure to make repairs needed for the premises to remain habitable, as required under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and relevant Massachusetts housing code provisions, including 105 CMR 410.750.
